<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Finding New York City directories in Hathitrust is a little like herding cattle: you find the first bunch quickly, and then spend the rest of your time rounding up strays. Instead of a long list of individual directories, searching Hathitrust yields a series of record sets into which the individual directories have been organized. Typically, a record set holds <a href="https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/100513654">various years from the same title</a>, but a single title may appear across two or more record sets, and sometimes a record set contains only one directory. In addition, many of the record sets associated with the subject heading "<em>New York (N.Y.) > Directories</em>" are not specifically <em>address</em> directories. This is when the search process begins to feel like a long, lonely cattle drive...</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>So before I could proceed, I first had to create my own mini-catalog: a little slice of Hathitrust, stored in a local data frame and dedicated to this project. My local catalog helps me keep track of what I've found so I don't waste time rounding up the same directories over and over again. I also use my local catalog to store bibliographic data associated with each directory--things like title, originating repository, and publication year. And as I convert the text pages stored on Hathitrust into a multi-year data frame of address entries, my local catalog helps me keep on top of where I am in the scraping, cleaning, and importing process.</p>
<p>Here's a snippet of the local catalog. I've omitted some columns for readability.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">sys</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">urllib.request</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">re</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">bs4</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">BeautifulSoup</span>

<span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_pickle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'../blogdata/catalog_snippet.p'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[1]:</div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I've already gathered the id numbers for nineteen record sets at Hathitrust, but there's every reason to think I'll find more in the future, so I wanted a script that could mine Hathitrust, store the data in local data frame, and add new data whenever I came across a new record set that I hadn't seen before.</p>
<p>To demonstrate that process here, I've already used the script to create a small local catalog that already contains data scraped from Hathitrust: five directories from the 1840s, all associated with record id number "100734456".</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_cat</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_pickle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'../blogdata/catalog_scrape.p'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_cat</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[2]:</div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now I'd like to add more directories to my local catalog, so I'll re-run the script, this time using three record numbers that I've found while searching for New York City directories in Hathitrust:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Create list of Hathitrust page ids for directory holdings</span>
<span class="n">ht_dirs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'100734456'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'008925998'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'012507789'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In Hathitrust, the stable URL for each set of records consists of a record number appended to a base URL. The script stores this base URL in a variable for use in the loop later. I'll also create a series of lists to store the data gathered during the loop. To build my local catalog, I'll scrape the title, publication year, last page number, and catalog number of each directory in the record set, as well as the name of the repository that donated the directory to Hathitrust.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># base url for directory holdings pages</span>
<span class="n">ht_url</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/'</span>

<span class="c1"># create lists to store data from loop</span>

<span class="n">source_id_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">record_id_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">cat_id_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">title_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">pub_year_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">total_pages_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
<span class="n">repository_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Before scraping, I check the list against the existing data frame in case I've scraped some of these record sets already. I've also added a few lines of code to anticipate the possibility that a user will run the script with an empty record list.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># return any record numbers that aren't already in the local catalog</span>
<span class="n">new_ht_dirs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">setdiff1d</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ht_dirs</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">df_cat</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">record_id</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># return any record numbers that duplicated those in the local catalog</span>
<span class="n">dup_ht_dirs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">setdiff1d</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ht_dirs</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">new_ht_dirs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># if the user ran the script with an empty record list, return an error message and exit.</span>
<span class="k">if</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ht_dirs</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">sys</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Please add record numbers to the list and rerun this script.'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># if any record ids already exist in the local catalog, let the user know which ones.</span>
<span class="k">if</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dup_ht_dirs</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Alert: The following records are already in the catalog data frame:</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="p">[</span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'  '</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">dup_ht_dirs</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="c1"># if there are new records to be added, let the user know which ones.</span>
<span class="k">if</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">new_ht_dirs</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">The following records are new and will be added to the catalog data frame:</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="p">[</span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'  '</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">new_ht_dirs</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="c1"># if all the records already exist in the local catalog, return an error message and exit.</span>
<span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">sys</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'No new records to add.'</span><span class="p">)</span>       
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>
Alert: The following records are already in the catalog data frame:

  100734456

The following records are new and will be added to the catalog data frame:

  008925998
  012507789
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this case, one of the three records in the list is already in the local data frame.  This information is reported to the user and the record is eliminated from the list.</p>
<p>The script now loops through the remaining items on the list, scraping information from hathitrust and storing it in a set of lists. Most of the data will be scraped from the main record page, but the last page number of each directory can only be obtained by following the link to that directory's page, so that part of the script gets a tiny bit tricky:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Loop through holdings pages, scraping info about directory catalog id, title,</span>
<span class="c1">## year of publication, repository name, and last page (total_pages)</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">new_ht_dirs</span> <span class="p">:</span>

    <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># create full url</span>
    <span class="n">myURL</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ht_url</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">rec_id</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Scraping '</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">myURL</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># retrieve that html and store as string variable</span>
    <span class="n">cat_html</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">urllib</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">request</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">urlopen</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">myURL</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read</span><span class="p">()</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># convert html to soup</span>
    <span class="n">soup</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">BeautifulSoup</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cat_html</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'lxml'</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="c1"># in main html, loop through 'span/IndItem' to get list of pub_years </span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">soup</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find_all</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'span'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">attrs</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'class'</span> <span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'IndItem'</span><span class="p">})</span> <span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">re</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">findall</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'\d</span><span class="si">{4}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
        <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">re</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">findall</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'\d</span><span class="si">{4}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">pub_year_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pub_year</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
        
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'  Holdings:  '</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">))</span>

    <span class="c1"># ...loop through 'em/original_from' to get list of repositories</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">soup</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find_all</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'em'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">attrs</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'class'</span> <span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'original_from'</span><span class="p">}):</span>
        
        <span class="n">repository</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'(original from '</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">')'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="n">repository</span> <span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">repository</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'unknown'</span>
        <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">repository</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'(original from '</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">')'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">repository_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">repository</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="c1"># ...loop through 'div/accessLinks' to get link to each directory</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">soup</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find_all</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'div'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">attrs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'id'</span> <span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'accessLinks'</span><span class="p">})</span> <span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="c1">#then loop through the links in that div and...</span>
        <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">link</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find_all</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'a'</span><span class="p">):</span>
            <span class="c1"># ...get the cat_id from each <a> and add to list</span>
            <span class="n">dir_address</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'https:'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">link</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'href'</span><span class="p">)</span>
            <span class="n">cat_id</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dir_address</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'2027/'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
            <span class="n">cat_id_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cat_id</span><span class="p">)</span>

            
            <span class="c1"># follow each link and grab the 'last page' url</span>
            <span class="n">dir_html</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">urllib</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">request</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">urlopen</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dir_address</span><span class="p">)</span>
            <span class="n">f</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dir_html</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read</span><span class="p">()</span>
            <span class="n">newsoup</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">BeautifulSoup</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'lxml'</span><span class="p">)</span>
            <span class="n">total_pages</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">newsoup</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'action-go-last'</span><span class="p">))</span>
            <span class="n">total_pages_parsed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">total_pages</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'seq='</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
            <span class="n">total_pages_parsed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">total_pages_parsed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">';'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'"'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
            <span class="n">total_pages_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_pages_parsed</span><span class="p">)</span>

    
    <span class="c1"># retrieve title from main html</span>
    <span class="n">title</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">soup</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">': '</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">' |'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="n">title</span> <span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">title</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'untitled'</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"  Title: "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">title_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">extend</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># created record_id_list</span>
    <span class="n">record_id_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">extend</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">rec_id</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Scraping https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008925998
  Holdings:  5
  Title: Longworth's American almanac, New-York...
Scraping https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/012507789
  Holdings:  1
  Title: The directory of the city of New York, 
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The script scrapes the pages of two record sets, finding five directories associated with the first record set and one with the second.</p>
<p>By this point, the script has collected all of the bibliographic data and stored it in lists. But before adding that data to the local data frame, I first need to create a unique source id for each directory. Down the road, I'll use the catalog as a dictionary so I can look up the publication year associated with each address entry, so I want a source number to use as a primary key:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># set up numbering for new additions to dataframe</span>
<span class="n">last_source_id</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">max</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_cat</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">source_id</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># count the number of new additions</span>
<span class="n">num_additions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cat_id_list</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span>

<span class="k">while</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o"><=</span> <span class="n">num_additions</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">source_id_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">last_source_id</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">i</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now that all of the data are collected, I'll convert the lists into pandas Series, specifying the data type:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">source_id_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">source_id_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">record_id_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">record_id_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">cat_id_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cat_id_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">title_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">pub_year_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pub_year_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">total_pages_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_pages_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">repository_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">repository_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># create empty series of correct lengeth for scraped, cleaned, and imported</span>
<span class="n">scraped_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cleaned_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">imported_pds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">num_additions</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>And now I'll combine the pandas Series into a single data frame using <em>concat</em>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># create a temporary dataframe from the lists    </span>
<span class="n">df_temp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">concat</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">source_id_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">record_id_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cat_id_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">title_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">pub_year_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                     <span class="n">total_pages_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">repository_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scraped_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cleaned_pds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">imported_pds</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># name the columns</span>
<span class="n">col_names</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'source_id'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'record_id'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'cat_id'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'title'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'pub_year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'total_pages'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
           <span class="s1">'repository'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'scraped'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'cleaned'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'imported'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">df_temp</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">col_names</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Finally, I'll append the new data to the existing data:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">

<p>Now that my local catalog is functioning, I can add new record sets to the project as I locate them, or as new ones arrive in Hathitrust. In meantime, I can begin <a href="https://historiscope.github.io/CSI-Part1.html">scraping, cleaning, and importing</a> the newly added directories.</p>

entry.title: Introducing the NYC Directory Project
entry.summary: The NYC Directory Project uses Python to extract data from nineteenth-century address directories that have been scanned and made publicly available on Hathitrust.org. The final result will be a demographic and geocoded dataset that can be searched and analyzed to learn more about the residents of New York City in the 1800s.

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The NYC Directory Project uses Python to extract data from nineteenth-century address directories that have been scanned and made publicly available on <a href="https://www.hathitrust.org">Hathitrust.org</a>. The final result will be a demographic and geocoded dataset that can be searched and analyzed to learn more about the residents of New York City in the 1800s.</p>
<p>Browsing through directories on <a href="https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Search/Home?type%5B%5D=subject&lookfor%5B%5D=%22%20New%20York%20%28N.Y.%29%20Directories.%22&filter%5B%5D=topicStr%3ANew%20York%20%28N.Y.%29%20Directories&ft=">Hathitrust</a> and at the <a href="https://www.nypl.org/blog/2016/09/21/new-york-city-directories-free-online">New York Public Library</a> and other sites, I was intrigued at the sheer quantity of data embedded there and struck by what could be learned and accomplished by using code to clean and structure it. Historical sources such as the <a href="https://archive.org/details/us_census">United States Federal Census</a> and the <a href="https://familysearch.org/search/collection/1491284">New York State Census</a> provide a useful picture of past New York City residents, but census data exists, at best, only at five-year intervals and prior to 1850, the census is <a href="https://www.thoughtco.com/digging-details-from-us-census-records-1421771">notably vague</a>.</p>
<p>Address directories have long been an alternative source of information for historians and genealogists. The scanning of address directories by Google, Archive.org, and others made them widely available so that getting access to them no longer required a physical trip to the repository that owned them. Even in digital format, however, they remained stubbornly analog, used primarily for locating individuals whose names were already known in an alphabetical index--just as originally intended. The production of text versions using OCR (optical character recognition) freed the directories from the tyranny of alphabetical order and made it possible to search the text by name, street, or occupation, for example.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, even with OCR, the utility of the address directories remains limited. You can text-search them, but you can't analyze them, and the inconsistent quality of OCR makes searching the directories a game of “hit or miss.” For example, in the image below, portions of the text were converted to cyrillic (anyone doing a text search for "Leedom, Widdifield & Cohn" is out of luck). In addition, the left and right columns ran together which will make parsing these address entries a special challenge.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<div align="center">
<figure>
<img alt="scanned directory page" src="images/NYC-1844.png" />
</figure>
<figure>
<img alt="OCR text" src="images/NYC-1844-ocr.png" />
<figcaption>
<sub><em>The New York City Directory, 1844/45</em>, at 
                <a href="https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=osu.32435056191521;view=1up;seq=217;size=150">Hathitrust</a>
</sub>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The NYC Directory Project is an effort to enhance the value of historical address directories by using <a href="https://www.python.org/about/gettingstarted/">Python</a> to access, clean, and structure the text, and by using statistical inference to identify different address formats and to fix OCR errors where possible. This process will make searching a single directory considerably more effective, but more importantly it will allow for the systematic analysis of data within and across address directories, providing an annual snapshot of New York City as it was (or at least, as it appeared in these directories; as I will discuss in a future post, the directories were far from a comprehensive accounting of the city’s population). And because address directories, happily, used fairly consistent formats, this project is portable: the same code--with the inevitable tweaking--can be used to unlock the past of other cities as well.</p>
<p>While this project contributes to a larger effort by Historiscope to extract and disseminate demographically meaningful data from publicly available digitized documents, it's also inspired by some personal goals. I began this project in part as a means to learn and practice writing Python code, a tool I just recently added to my wheelhouse. I <a href="mailto:info@historiscope.org">welcome and encourage</a> suggestions and corrections.</p>
<p>Also, somewhere in those directories are the friends and relatives of my elusive ancestor William Peck Sims, a New York City wheelwright born around 1810 and a lifelong resident of old New York. Using the Python-enhanced version of these directories, I hope to get to know him and his world a little better.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

            <a href="https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=chi.102184102;view=1up;seq=510">Hathitrust</a>
</sub>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
